org.billtorcaso.kutils
Interface Stopwatch

All Known Implementing Classes:
StopwatchImpl, StopwatchNoOpImpl
@ThreadSafe
public interface Stopwatch

The Stopwatch interface records an sequence of named moments, with nanosecond intervals and minimal run-time overhead.

The original purpose was to provide hierarchical measures of time spent doing I/O, but Stopwatch is not limited to that. The typical use-case is to record many moments of interest and analyze them afterwards.

This Interface is (intended to be) thread-safe. Implementation classes must be final in order to preserve thread-safety.

A Stopwatch object provides only relative nanosecond measures. As such it records moments and can provide the elapsed time between two moments.

A moment has a title, which is a String that identifies it. It does not have to be unique among the titles of a Stopwatch.

A Stopwatch cannot be started, reset, or stopped. Create another Stopwatch object if you get tired of the one you have.

A moment is represented in an immutable inner-class object named Moment. A Moment object contains two accessors, one for the result of System.timeNanos() and one for the title of the Moment. A Moment object can only be instantiated by the Stopwatch method momentsRetrieve.

A Moment can be identified as the beginning of a task, the end of a task or just a plain moment. The distinction between a moment, a beginning, and an ending is only relevant to the prettyPrint() method.

A Stopwatch object does not enforce any ordering among beginnings and endings. If they are unbalanced, prettyPrint will display complete information but lose the pretty indenting.

A Stopwatch object is a mutable object and can grow without bounds. It grows by calls to any of these methods: 

     momentRecord()

     taskBegin()

     taskEnd()

These methods reach return a long value that is the elapsed time since the time of the previous recorded moment. See prettyPrint() and toString() for other measures of the time between moments.

A Stopwatch object always records the moment of its creation, and the return from the first moment-recording call will be the elapsed time since the creation of the Stopwatch object.

Note that there is no service that returns the time elapsed between any two particular moments. You must either track those two moments yourself, or post-process the result of momentsRetrieve.

By convention, implementation classes are forbidden from providing constructors. All concrete object implementations of this Interface must be obtained from class-static factory methods.

See Also:
StopwatchFactory, StopwatchInstance

Method Detail

momentRecord

long momentRecord(java.lang.String title)
Record a named moment.

Parameters:
title - the text to use as the identifier of this moment.
Returns:
a long that is the elapsed time since the previous moment was recorded. If no previous moment has been recorded using momentRecord(), taskBegin(), or taskEnd(), the elapsed time interval measures the time between the creation of the Stopwatch object and this call.

taskBegin

long taskBegin(java.lang.String title)
Record the beginning of a named task.

Parameters:
title - the text to use as the identifier of this moment. The title is prefixed with the text "TaskBegin:".
Returns:
a long that is the elapsed time since the previous moment was recorded. If no moments have been recorded using momentRecord(), taskBegin(), or taskEnd(), the elapsed time interval measures the time between the creation of the Stopwatch object and this call.

taskEnd

long taskEnd(java.lang.String title)
Record the end of a named task.

Parameters:
title - the text to use as the identifier of this moment. The title is prefixed with the text "TaskEnd:".
Returns:
a long that is the elapsed time since the previous moment was recorded. If no moments have been recorded using momentRecord(), taskBegin(), or taskEnd(), the elapsed time interval measures the time between the creation of the Stopwatch object and this call.

titleGet

java.lang.String titleGet()
Return the title string that was used when the Stopwatch was created. This string will never be null. It may be an empty ("") string.

Returns:
a String that is the title of this Stopwatch object.

momentsRetrieve

java.util.List<Stopwatch.Moment> momentsRetrieve(Stopwatch.IntervalReportType intervalType)
Return a List of Moment objects that represents the state of the Stopwatch at the time of the call. This method is thread-safe and returns a copy of the Stopwatch state. Changes in the list are not reflected in the Stopwatch itself.

The return value may be an empty list, but it will never be null.

Note that if multiple threads use the same Stopwatch object, the List may contain Moments that the current thread did not create.

Parameters:
intervalType - a Stopwatch.IntervalReportType object.
Returns:
a List containing Moment objects, in the order in which they were recorded by the Stopwatch.

toStringAsIntervals

java.lang.String toStringAsIntervals(Stopwatch.IntervalReportType thisReportType)
Return a String representation of the Moments in this Stopwatch, in which the representation of the time-interval of the Moment is selected from one of the Stopwatch.IntervalReportType values.

Parameters:
thisReportType - a Stopwatch.IntervalReportType object.
Returns:
a String representation of the Moments in this Stopwatch
See Also:
IntervalReportType

toString

java.lang.String toString()
Represent the Stopwatch's internal state in a String. The returned String presents each Moment in the Stopwatch, in order, with each Moment separated by an embedded "\n" newline character. Moment.toString() is called to create the String representation of each Moment object.

Overrides:
toString in class java.lang.Object

prettyPrint

java.lang.String prettyPrint(Stopwatch.IntervalReportType thisType)
Produce a nicely-formated text representation of the Stopwatch and its recorded moments, displaying intervals between Moments in the given IntervalReportType. This differs from toString() in that the text lines are indented to show the nesting of TaskBegin and TaskEnd moments. There is an implementation-defined limit to depth of indentation.

If the caller has not provided balanced calls to taskBegin() and taskEnd(), or the indentation limit has been excceded, the output will be complete but will not be pretty.

Parameters:
thisType - a value of the Enum type Stopwatch.IntervalReportType that controls the representation of time-intervals in a Moment.
Returns:
a String representing the recordedMoments of this Stopwatch, with TaskBegin / TaskEnd pairs having equal indentation.

prettyPrint

java.lang.String prettyPrint()
Produce a nicely-formated text representation of the Stopwatch and its recorded moments, using the creationMomentRelative format.

This convenience method is equivalent to prettyPrint(Stopwatch.IntervalReportType.previousMomentRelative).

Returns:
a String representing the recordedMoments of this Stopwatch, with TaskBegin / TaskEnd pairs having equal indentation.
See Also:
prettyPrint(Stopwatch.IntervalReportType thisType)
